subject: clarification - reading from XML file
msgSnippet: Thanks for your suggestions everyone (please see my original mail attached below). But the problem I am having is this - the classes are complex, hence
messageBody:
Thanks for your suggestions everyone (please see my original mail
attached below).

But the problem I am having is this - the classes are complex, hence
constructing classes with test data (so I can check against the data
read from file) is very cumbersome. Also, with equals() method I
cannot know which data member in the class actually caused a mis-
match, since I assert only at the class level.

This is why I am thinking what to do... hope this clarifies the
problem. Any suggestions would be appreciated. Thanks again for your
help so far.

- krishnan

pisharath_k wrote:

> I have a basic question. I have a set of classes whose values are
set
> from a file by a Reader object. Now I want to test whether these
> values are set correctly. I can use preset values for testing
> purpose. But due to the large number and complexity of these classes
> it would be very difficult and cumbersome to create objects with
> these preset values manually for testing against the ones created by
> the Reader.
>
> I am thinking of creating a helper class for each of the above
> classes. I will pass it the object to compare, and it will compare
> the object's data against pre-defined values that will be stored in
> the helper classes. I will need to extend junit's Assert class for
> these helper class, since they will assert if there is a data
> mismatch. So my question is, is it okay to extend Assert in my own
> classes ? Has anyone faced this problem before, and if so how did
you
> solve this ? Any help will be appreciated.
>
> Thanks,
> - krishnan
